prenatal.title: Prenatal Care
prenatal.description: Comprehensive guidance for expectant mothers during pregnancy
prenatal.theory:
Prenatal care is the healthcare you receive during your pregnancy. It involves regular check-ups, screenings, and education to ensure both you and your baby stay healthy. Starting prenatal care early and continuing it throughout pregnancy significantly reduces the risk of complications.

During your prenatal visits, your healthcare provider will monitor your baby's development, track your health, and address any concerns you might have. These visits typically include weight checks, blood pressure monitoring, urine tests, and measurements of your baby's growth.

As your pregnancy progresses, you'll also undergo various screenings and tests, such as ultrasounds, blood tests, and possibly genetic testing, depending on your age, health history, and preferences. These tests help identify potential issues early, allowing for timely intervention if needed.
mentalWellness: Practice daily mindfulness meditation for 10-15 minutes to reduce anxiety and stress
Join a pregnancy support group to connect with other expectant mothers
Maintain a pregnancy journal to express your thoughts and track your journey
Communicate openly with your partner about your feelings and concerns
Set realistic expectations and don't hesitate to ask for help when needed
Ensure you get adequate sleep and rest throughout the day
babyCare: Take prenatal vitamins as recommended by your healthcare provider
Stay hydrated by drinking at least 8-10 glasses of water daily
Eat a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains
Avoid alcohol, tobacco, and caffeine during pregnancy
Monitor your baby's movements daily in the third trimester
Prepare for labor by learning breathing techniques and relaxation methods

postnatal.title: Postnatal Care
postnatal.description: Essential guidance for new mothers after childbirth
postnatal.theory:
Postnatal care, also known as postpartum care, refers to the support and medical attention provided to new mothers and their babies after childbirth. This period typically covers the first six weeks after delivery, though many aspects of recovery and adjustment continue beyond this timeframe.

Physical recovery from childbirth varies for each woman. Your body undergoes significant changes as it returns to its pre-pregnancy state. You may experience vaginal discharge (lochia), breast engorgement, perineal pain, and fatigue. It's important to rest as much as possible, stay hydrated, and eat nutritious foods to support your recovery.

Emotional well-being is equally important during this time. Many new mothers experience mood swings, known as the 'baby blues,' due to hormonal changes. However, if feelings of sadness or anxiety persist or worsen, it could indicate postpartum depression, which requires professional help.
mentalWellness: Accept help from family and friends for household chores and baby care
Prioritize sleep whenever possible, even if it means napping when your baby naps
Connect with other new mothers through support groups or online communities
Set aside time for self-care, even if it's just 15 minutes a day
Communicate openly with your partner about your feelings and needs
Remember that it's okay to not feel okay - seek professional help if needed
babyCare: Learn to recognize your baby's hunger cues and feed on demand
Practice proper latch techniques if breastfeeding to prevent soreness
Change diapers frequently to prevent diaper rash
Support your baby's head and neck when holding or carrying them
Establish a simple routine for feeding, sleeping, and bathing
Monitor your baby's weight gain and development at regular check-ups
